defaultSeo.metaDescription: BearPaw U is on a Legal Education Mission to make online learning as fun, rewarding, and fast as possible! Earn BearBucks for each completed course and swap 'em for some sweet SWAG!

attributes.title: Missing 101
attributes.description: If someone in your family or community has gone missing, you need to get the facts quick. Join BearPaw U Professor Cayenne for the 101 on Reporting a Missing Person in Alberta. We will also explore the issue of historical distrust between Indigenous communities and the police - and how that distrust can impact the search for our people.

contentBlocks.sectionContent:
BearPaw U has the 101 for you when it comes to reporting a missing person in Alberta. Keep scrolling to get all the facts, including:

- Is someone missing?
- Before you call police
- Police investigations 

Missing 101 will also explore historical distrust between our Indigenous communities and the police - and how that relationship can impact whether we pick up the phone to make a report, or not.

**Plus, if you get all the way down to the bottom of the page, take Professor Cayenne’s Spicy Quiz for some sweet, and free, BearPaw U Swag!**

If someone is missing, you can report it to the police right away.  There is no 24 or 72-hour waiting period. You can call anytime. You don’t have to be a family member or even live in the same city.

If a person is under 12, elderly, or has  disabilities, call 911 immediately.

For someone to be missing, it would mean that: 
- They have not been in contact with people they normally are
- They are absent from the places they usually are 
- Their location is unknown despite reasonable efforts to locate them

If someone you know is missing, it is very important to reach out for support. A support can be an Elder, family member, friend, or advocate. 

Cultural practices like smudging and ceremony can balance us during difficult times. Exercise and going for walks helps with stress too. To learn more about wellness, grief, and trauma, check out our Wellness Guide for Indigenous Families.

Here is a quick checklist if you are trying to find someone. Check: 

- Family, including in other communities or provinces
- Friends and acquaintances
- Foster families
- School or work
- Social media for posts/updates/mentions 
- Area Hospitals or shelters
- In a program?
- Places where they go often

If you are not sure if someone is missing, ask yourself: 

_“Is this out of character for them?”_

While anyone can go missing for a variety of reasons, there are groups of people that are at higher risk than others:

- Youth under the age of 18 years account for over half of the missing persons in Canada
- People suffering from mental health issues

Other reasons:

- Deliberate disappearance
- Drifting, transience
- Adventure or accident
- Mental Health issues – undiagnosed or untreated mental health illnesses, addictions may be a factor
- Suicide
- Foul play

If you are ready to make the report, call your local police detachment. When you speak to the police, make your call and concern sound like a priority.  

Police are legally required to do an assessment of a missing persons report. They will ask many questions, and some may feel invasive. It can be difficult to share the answers. 

You’ll be asked questions such as physical description, health, lifestyle, and circumstances. 

Police may also ask questions like:

- Last person spoken to or seen with
- Is this behavior out of character?
- On medication or immediate health concerns?
- Addictions issues?
- Suicidal?
- Involved in gangs, drugs, or the sex-trade?

Try to provide police with as much information as you can.  The report will be dispatched to patrol officers.

contentBlocks.tipText:
Always ask for the case file # and the name and badge # of every police officer you talk to

If a missing person is not found in a few days, the case will be transferred to the Missing Persons Unit.
contentBlocks.tipTitle: BearPaw Tip for U - Calling the Police

contentBlocks.sectionContent:
Picking up the phone and calling the police for help is not easy for many Indigenous people in Alberta.  In families and communities, there remains a distrust of the police based on Canada’s history of colonization. 

This continued distrust can prevent people from making a report, or if they do, they hold back information.

This distrust goes back generations to the times of residential school, when it was the Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) who often took children away. 

And it was the police, who years later, were taking our kids to the child welfare system. 

And, it was the police, who apologized to the families of missing and murdered Indigenous women after a national inquiry:

>
_“I’m sorry that for too many of you, the RCMP was not the police service that it needed to be during this terrible time in your life. It is very clear to me that the RCMP could have done better and I promise to you we will do better."_
RCMP Commissioner Brenda Lucki, 2018

In order to find a missing person, try to build a trusting relationship with the police officers at your local station or detachment.

In 2011, the RCMP themselves released a report titled "The Role of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police during the Indian Residential School system".

Some of the report's findings:

- There was a lack of trust between Indigenous Peoples and the RCMP
- The RCMP were used as a threat against parents to get the children to go to school
 - The threat of police action by Indian Agents and church officials was used to obtain compliance from Indigenous people
- Many former students claimed they learned to fear the RCMP. As a result, many people didn't try to contact police

So, as you can see, picking up the phone sometimes is not so easy.

Want to know what the National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women said about the relationship between the police and the community? Here is a small section from the Inquiry’s Calls for Justice:


When the unthinkable happens and families become concerned that their loved one may be missing or in danger of violence, they are faced with a difficult dilemma: 

- to seek help in finding that loved one requires reaching out to institutions (police) that have historically ignored and continue to ignore their concerns 
- forced to reach out to institutions that are directly at the heart of significant pain, division, cultural destruction, and trauma experienced in their family and perhaps by the loved one they seek help in finding
- If families do reach out to the police or another representative of the criminal justice system, they are often confronted with an individual, policy, procedure, or way of relating that shows little to no awareness or understanding of the histories of and complexities in the relationship between Indigenous Peoples and the police
- Instead, within this institution, the family and their lost loved one are viewed through a lens of pervasive racist and sexist stereotypes
- This stereotyping and mistrust creates a reluctance to reach out to the police for help
- On a much larger scale, the historic denial of and unwillingness to investigate the disappearances or deaths of many Indigenous people have, for many years, sent the message that the police are indifferent to such violence

When police in Alberta receive a missing persons report, they assess the report based on a number of vulnerability factors, including: 

- age 
- physical health 
- mental health and competency 
- emotional state
- lifestyle factors 
- circumstances
- prior involvement with police 
- environmental conditions

A missing person is considered high risk if:

- Alzheimer patient/wanderer
- Over 80 years of age
- 12 years of age and younger
- A victim or witness in recent or future court proceedings
- Suicidal
- Involved in suspicious circumstances
- A person who is endangered due to mental health concerns

Missing people are considered missing until located. The case will only be closed once the person has been found. 

Open files are reviewed periodically, at minimum – at 3 months, 6 months, 1 year and every 2 years after.  

# Contact with police and support

The Primary Investigator at the Missing Persons Unit is the families main contact with the police. They can give you advice and help you understand the investigation.

The Alberta Victims Services Family Liaison Unit provide supports to families of missing Indigenous people. They can help:  
- Communicate with police
- Decide which actions to take 
- Cope through the process 

Family Information Liaison Unit: 780-427-3460 or toll free 310-0000

Write everything down. Including:
- Contact information for the police officers you speak to 
- Detailed notes with dates  

If you are a computer person: 
- Create a folder on your desktop to save all your files in
- Organize emails into a specific folder in your email

--

- You can phone your investigator if you would like an update. Keep in mind that in order to protect the integrity of the investigation, the police may not be able to tell you everything

- If you start to get information from people on social media – screenshot those conversations 

# What if a file isn’t opened?

If the police do not open a file right away, call the police again:

- If new information becomes available 
- If the person remains missing for a longer period of time 

Sometimes you may feel the police are not working in a manner you are happy with and you would like to make a complaint about the investigator. 

Before you do that, take the time to speak to their supervisor or the head of 
their unit or section. 

# Searching for more?

Here is some additional information from the government of Alberta on reporting a missing person:

https://www.alberta.ca/report-missing-person.aspx#jumplinks-2
Congratulations! You made it! Answer 3 out of 4 questions correctly and a receive a coupon code for some sweet, and free, BearPaw U swag!

contentBlocks.Question: How long do you have to wait before you can report someone missing?

Answers.Answer: There is no requirement to wait you can report at any time

contentBlocks.Question: If you call police to make a missing person report, it is important to:

Answers.Answer: Withhold information from the police that may make people look bad
Be ready to answer questions, which may feel invasive

contentBlocks.Question: Historical distrust between Indigenous communities and the police can be traced back to:
Who is the families main contact with the Missing Persons Unit?

Answers.Answer: The officer who took the original call
